questions.text: On watching the documentary 'The Secret of Our Lives: The Human Genome Project', a student reads up about the international consortium of scientists who fully deciphered the DNA of the most common chromosomal syndrome. What is this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Trisomy 21 (Down’s syndrome) is the most common chromosomal syndrome. It is the second human chromosome whose DNA has been fully deciphered by the Human Genome Project.

Chromosomal disorders: These may involve autosomal or sex chromosomes.

Involving autosomes

Involving sex chromosomes

Down’s syndrome (Trisomy 21)

Edward syndrome (Trisomy 18)

Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13)

Cri du chat syndrome (5p deletion)

Klinefelter’s syndrome (47, XXY)

Turner syndrome (45, X0)

Note:

  • Most common trisomy leading to miscarriage/incompatibility with life: Trisomy 16.
  • F body: Y chromosome (quinacrine, a fluorescence dye, binds strongly to the Y chromosome forming a bright fluorescent spot called an F body).

questions.text: A 39-year-old pregnant woman was found to have an abnormal nuchal translucency scan. An amniocentesis done revealed a chromosomal karyotype of 47, XX,+21. This result most commonly occurs due to?
questions.solution:
The chromosomal karyotype of 47, XX,+21 is suggestive of Down’s syndrome which occurs due to nondisjunction in maternal meiosis. Non-disjunction points to the failure of the homologous chromosome to separate during the meiotic division.

Down’s syndrome:

  • Most common chromosomal disorder
  • Incidence: 1/800 live births
  • Mechanism:
    • Trisomy 21 (meiotic maternal nondisjunction) (95%)
    • Robertsonian translocation: 4%
    • Mosaic pattern: 1%

Note:

  • Robertsonian translocations: involve 2 acrocentric chromosomes (chromosomes 13, 14, 15, 21, and 22) that fuse near the centromeric region, with a subsequent loss of the short arms.

questions.text: Your aunt has sent you an image of her 1-year-old son's palm using an instant messaging app. She read online that it is mostly present in genetic disorders and wishes to get your opinion. You identify it as a simian crease and prepare a list of differentials. All of the following diagnoses are correct except:
questions.solution:
Simian crease (single transverse palmar crease) is not seen in cystic fibrosis. 

Simian crease is seen in the following disorders:

  • Down's syndrome
  • Fetal alcohol syndrome
  • Trisomy 13
  • Cri du chat syndrome

questions.text: A girl is born at term after an uneventful pregnancy and delivery. On examination, she is noted to be hypotonic, has a protruding tongue, low set ears, an upward slant to the eyes with epicanthal folds, and a single palmar crease. On cardiac evaluation, what is the most common lesion expected in this syndrome?
questions.solution:
The girl is suffering from Down’s syndrome and the most common cardiovascular lesion is an endocardial cushion defect.

Other associated defects are atrial septum defects (ASD), ventricular septum defect (VSD), patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), aberrant subclavian artery, and pulmonary hypertension.

 Clinical features: (Mnemonic: I C A PROBLEM Somewhere)

  • Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukaemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the duodenum
  • Protruding tongue
  • Round face
  • Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth
  • Brachycephalic/Brushfield's spots
  • Low (depressed) nasal bridge
  • Epicanthal fold/Ears low set and dysplastic
  • Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure)
  • Simian palmar crease and wider gap between first and second toes

Note:

  • The most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down syndrome is duodenal atresia (double-bubble sign).
  • Children with Down's syndrome have an increased risk of developing leukaemias, including acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukaemia (AML). 
  • AML is more common during the first 3 years of life.
  • The most common AML associated with Down Syndrome is acute megakaryoblastic leukemia.
  • The most common haematological manifestation in Downs syndrome is transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM).
  • Brushfield's spots are whitish speckling on iris seen in light-skinned people.

Image: A child having features of Down’s syndrome

Image: Brushfield's spots

World Down Syndrome Day is observed annually on March 21, 21st day of 3rd month, signifies trisomy 21. The theme for the year 2023 is "With Us Not For Us", signifying a human rights-based approach where people with disabilities have the right to be treated fairly & have the same opportunities as everyone else, working With others to improve their lives.

questions.text: A 41-year-old entrepreneur is excited to start her family. She has been getting a lot of unsolicited advice about the complications of pregnancy in advanced maternal age. On enquiring about such pregnancies, the doctor advised the mother to get prenatal testing done. All are findings associated with the prenatal diagnosis for Down’s syndrome except _________

choices.text: Ventricular septal defect may be present

questions.solution:
Increased umbilical flow is not seen during the prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome, instead, the flow is decreased.

Reduced blood flow through the umbilical vessels and abnormal blood flow through ductus venosus (DV) in the first trimester are associated with chromosomal abnormalities, especially Down's syndrome. This decrease in blood flow causes IUGR in infants born with Down syndrome.

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

questions.text: An elderly primigravida underwent a nuchal translucency scan at 14 weeks which was highly suggestive of Down’s syndrome. The doctor advised her to undergo a triple test and called her back at week 16. On receiving her receipt for the payment of the test, she realises that she has been billed wrongly for a component that is not included in the triple test. What is this component?
questions.solution:
Inhibin A is not included in the triple test:

Test Components
Triple test AFP + hCG + UE3
Quadruple test Triple test + Inhibin A
Combined test
(first-trimester screening)		 PAPPA + hCG + nuchal translucency
Integrated test
(most sensitive)		 Combined test + Quadruple test

Note:

  • AFP: Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein
  • HCG: Beta-human chorionic gonadotrophin
  • PAPPA: Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A
  • UE3: Unconjugated estriol

questions.text: While writing your medical competitive exams, you come across the following image of karyotyping analysis in a question. You recognize this image as being highly suggestive of a particular syndrome.  What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above karyotype is suggestive of Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13).

Clinical features of Trisomy 13/Patau syndrome (Mnemonic CMC DOCToR OPD)

  • Cardiac defects (ventricular septal defect/atrial septal defect/patent ductus arteriosus)
  • Microcephaly, Microphthalmia
  • Cleft lip/palate
  • Developmental delay
  • Ocular hypotelorism
  • Holoprosencephaly
  • Thin posterior ribs (missing ribs)
  • Renal abnormalities
  • Polydactyly with flexed fingers
  • Polycystic kidneys
  • Scalp defects (aplasia cutis)

Image: 37-week male with Patau syndrome demonstrating alobar holoprosencephaly with cyclopia. Facial features included a sloping forehead with a nose superior to a single central palpebral fissure.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy presented with facial dysmorphism as well as two characteristic findings shown in the picture below. What is the condition affecting this newborn?
questions.solution:
The newborn with features of facial dysmorphism, index finger overlapping other fingers, and rocker bottom feet are suggestive of Edward’s syndrome (Trisomy 18).

Clinical features of Edward’s syndrome: (Remember mnemonic: Hi Mr EDWARDS)

  • Hypertonia
  • Microcephaly/Micrognathia
  • Eighteen trisomy/Elongated skull
  • Digit overlapping with a closed fist
  • Webbing of 2nd and 3rd toes
  • Absent intellect (severe developmental delay)/Absent radii/ Arthrogryposis
  • Rocker bottom feet
  • Cardiac Disorders (ventricular septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, atrial septal defect) and kidney, death.
  • Small lower jaw (Micrognathia), short sternum, small nipples

Note: P, Patau syndrome: Trisomy 13

         E, Edward's syndrome: Trisomy 18

         D, Down syndrome: Trisomy 21

Alagille syndrome (AS) is an autosomal-dominant disorder associated with abnormalities of the liver (hypoplasia of hepatic duct), heart (tetralogy of Fallot), skeleton, eye, and kidneys and a characteristic facial appearance. 

William's syndrome is a developmental disorder that is characterized by mild to moderate intellectual disability or learning problems, unique personality characteristics, distinctive facial features, and cardiovascular problems.

questions.text: A young girl presents to you with learning disabilities.  On examination, you notice a characteristic finding as shown in the picture below. Reports of her investigation scans mention horseshoe kidneys and streak gonads. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child shows characteristic webbed neck, learning disabilities, horseshoe kidneys, and streak gonads and is diagnosed with Turner’s syndrome.

Turner’s syndrome:

  • Karyotype, 45; XO, phenotypically females
  • Chromosomal abnormality XO is present in 60% of individuals, mosaic pattern in 40%
  • Intelligence remains normal

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome: (mnemonic: See A Baby CLOWN Here)

  • Short stature, Short fourth metacarpal, Sensorineural hearing loss, Shield chest
  • Amenorrhea (primary), infertility
  • Barr body absent
  • Cardiac defects, Cubitus valgus, Congenital lymphedema
  • L: Learning disabilities
  • Ovaries underdeveloped (streak ovaries), Gonadoblastoma (increased risk if Y chromosome material is present)
  • Webbed neck
  • Nipples widely spaced
  • Horseshoe kidneys

Note:

The most common cardiac defect in Turner's is bicuspid aortic valve > coarctation of aorta.

In Noonan's syndrome, the females are usually fertile and horseshoe kidneys are rarely seen.

questions.text: Kaveri recently became pregnant following a history of repeated abortions. She was anxious and wanted to undergo karyotyping this time to detect chromosomal disorders pre-natally. Barr body was found to be absent in her report. Which of the following is associated with an absent Barr body?
questions.solution:
Barr body is absent in female having 45 X0 genome.

Barr body

  • Densely staining inactivated condensed X chromosome present in each somatic cell of a female is found in the nucleus.
  • Chromatid body (Barr body or sex chromatin) is derived from one of the two X chromosomes which become inactivated.
  • The number of Barr bodies is thus one less than the number of X chromosomes.

Turner's syndrome is female without Barr body.

Klinefelter's syndrome is male with Barr body.

Note:

  • Lyon hypothesis states that only one of the two X chromosomes in a female is functional, the other becomes inactive during embryogenesis.
  • Davidson bodies are small nuclear buds of chromatin shaped like a drumstick found in neutrophils of females.

questions.text: A 15-year-old adolescent presents with an anti-mongoloid slant, pulmonary stenosis, short stature, webbed neck, and undescended testis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The adolescent presenting with antimongoloid slant, pulmonary stenosis, short stature, webbed neck, and undescended testis is suggestive of Noonan syndrome. Although the webbed neck is a feature of Turner syndrome as well, the likely diagnosis would be Noonan syndrome since the patient is male (undescended testis). 

Noonan syndrome:

  • Autosomal-dominant disorder (12q)
  • Male or female with Turner phenotype; normal karyotype.

Clinical features:

  • Down-slanting palpebral fissure (antimongoloid slant)
  • Pectus carinatum
  • Hypertelorism
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Low levels of clotting factor 11 and 12
  • Leukemia (Juvenile chronic myelogenous leukemia)
  • Moderate mental retardation in 25%
  • Cardiac abnormality: Most common is pulmonary valve stenosis.
    • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
    • Atrial Septal Defect
    • Coarctation of aorta
  • Short stature, webbed neck, low set ears, cubitus valgus: similarities with Turner syndrome
  • Ptosis, micrognathia, clinodactyly, delayed puberty.

Difference between Noonan syndrome and Turner syndrome:

Noonan syndrome

Turner syndrome

Normal karyotype(46XX/46XY)

45, X0 (60%)

Most common heart disease: Valvular pulmonary stenosis

Most common heart disease: Bicuspid aortic valve

25% have mental retardation

Mental retardation rare

Genitourinary:

Female: Fertile, delayed puberty

Male: Infertile due to cryptorchidism

Genitourinary:

Female: Infertile, streak ovaries

No males

questions.text: A concerned pregnant woman underwent karyotyping which was highly suggestive of a particular syndrome. The image of her results is shown below. Which of the following abnormalities is associated with patients with the given karyotype?
questions.solution:
The above karyotype - 47, XXY, is suggestive of Klinefelter’s syndrome, in which gynecomastia and long thin limbs are seen.

Klinefelter’s syndrome:

  • Most common sex aneuploidy in males
  • Classically karyotype is 47, XXY. Other variants can have 48 XXXY; rarely, 49 XXXXY; or mosaics with some cells containing normal 46, XY and others 47, XXY
  • Results from meiotic nondisjunction of sex chromosomes (mostly during 1st meiotic division)

Clinical features:

  • Disproportionately long arms and legs
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Mental retardation; IQ: 60-80
  • Minor developmental and learning disabilities
  • Lack of secondary sexual characteristics (due to a decrease in androgen production)
  • Gynecomastia
  • Higher risk of breast carcinoma
  • Testicular dysgenesis
  • Infertility/ azoospermia

Note:

A variant of Klinefelter’s syndrome—49, XXXXY—presents with short stature.

questions.text: A newborn with previously diagnosed Cri-du-chat syndrome presented to the hospital. Which of the following is not observed in this condition?
questions.solution:
Hypotonia is seen in cri-du-chat syndrome, not hypertonia.

Cri-du-chat syndrome occurs due to the deletion of chromosome 5p.

Main features:

    • Hypotonia
    • Characteristic shrill cry (cat-like cry) in the first few weeks of life
    • Microcephaly
    • Hypertelorism
    • Bilateral epicanthic folds
    • High-arched palate
    • Wide and flat nasal bridge
    • Intellectual disability

Note:

  • Cat-bite infection is caused by Pasteurella multocida.
  • Tomcat urine odor is seen in multiple carboxylase deficiencies.

questions.text: A senior asks you to read about an autosomal dominant condition known as Treacher- Collins syndrome. While browsing through numerous journals to learn about the topic, you come across a doubt about its features. Which of the following is not associated with this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Intelligence is not affected in Treacher–Collins syndrome (like in Turners syndrome).

Treacher–Collins syndrome/Franceschetti syndrome

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Facial appearance: downward sloping palpebral fissures, colobomas and drooping of the lower eyelids, sunken cheekbones, deformed pinnae, atypical hair growth extending towards cheeks
  • Facial clefts, malformed ears, deafness
  • Hypoplastic mandible

 

Image: Treacher–Collins syndrome; note the sunken cheekbones, abnormality of ears, and hypoplastic mandible

questions.text: All of the following are seen in a 5-month-old child with Pierre- Robin syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Coloboma iris is not a feature of Pierre–Robin syndrome.

Features of Pierre–Robin syndrome-

  • Micrognathia accompanied by a high-arched or cleft palate
  • Tongue normal size; the floor of the mouth is foreshortened
  • Retrognathia: retracted mandible
  • Glossoptosis/Retroglossoptosis: tongue appears to fall into the throat (retraction of the tongue)

     

Of the children with Pierre–Robin syndrome, 30–50% have Stickler syndrome. Features include prominent joints, arthritis, hypotonia, hypermobile joints, mitral valve prolapse, hearing loss, and ocular problems (myopia, glaucoma, cataracts, retinal detachment).

questions.text: Shantanu, an avid reader, and a first-year resident, recently finished Joseph Heller's famous novel 'Catch-22'. While discussing the book with his friend, he realized that the title was an acronym of a chromosomal disorder they had studied. Which of the following is the least likely feature of this disorder?
questions.solution:
DiGeorge syndrome, also known as Catch-22 syndrome, is associated with cardiac anomalies and not cranial anomalies.

DiGeorge/Shprintzen Velocardiofacial syndrome - Remember the mnemonic CATCH 22

  • C: Cardiac anomalies
  • A: Abnormal facies
  • T: Thymic aplasia and agenesis of parathyroid glands.
  • C: Cleft palate
  • H: Hypocalcemia, hypoplasia of auricle
  • 22: 22q11.2 deletion

questions.text: Riya was found to have a height of more than 95 percentile for her age and an arm-span to height ratio of more than 1.05. On further examination, she had flat feet, mild scoliosis, and long slender fingers. An image of her hands showing two characteristic signs is provided below. What other complications can be expected in this child?
questions.solution:
The given features are suggestive of a diagnosis of Marfan's syndrome. Subluxation of the lens is a known complication. 

Image (a) shows Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist.

Image (b) shows Steinberg (thumb) sign - thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist

Features of Marfan's syndrome (Mnemonic: MARFAN’S)

  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Myopia due to upward dislocation of the lens (bilateral ectopic lentis)
  • Aortic root dilatation, Aortic regurgitation
  • Retinal detachment
  • Fibrillin 1 gene defect: Reduced fibrillin 1 production causing joint laxity
  • Fifteen (Chromosome 15 is involved)
  • Flat feet
  • Arachnodactyly, Astigmatism, Air in lungs (Pneumothorax)
  • Nearsightedness
  • Subluxation of lens, Scoliosis, Speech disorders, Sleep apnea

The image given below shows the Steinberg (thumb) sign:

questions.text: Venkatesh decided to present a rare case report of maternal disomy of chromosome 15 at a scientific conference. He collected the following image representing the disorder's features. What is this disorder?
questions.solution:
Maternal disomy of chromosome 15 is seen in Prader–Willi syndrome. The image shows the characteristic features of truncal obesity, short stature, and small hands and feet.

Uniparental disomy: Offspring receives both copies of a chromosome from 1 parent and no copies from the other parent.

  Prader-Willi syndrome  AngelMan syndrome
Deletion 

Paternal chromosome 15

Maternal chromosome 15
Uniparental Disomy Maternal disomy (duplication) seen in 25% of cases  Paternal disomy (duplication) seen in 5% of cases  
Clinical features

Elevated Ghrelin levels: Loss of appetite control, obesity

Severe hypotonia

Short stature

Small hands and feet

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

Cognitive impairment

Short stature

Severe mental retardation with lack of speech

Stiff arm movements

Spastic, uncoordinated walk

Seizures

An inappropriate outburst of laughter (Happy puppets)

Chromosome 15 diseases: Chromosome 15 has its own MAP (mnemonic),

  • M: Marfan syndrome
  • A: Angelman syndrome
  • P: Prader Willi syndrome

questions.text: Triangular facies is indicative of which of the following diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Triangular facies is indicative of Russell–Silver syndrome.

Russell–Silver syndrome: 

  • Clinical features: Short stature, triangular face (small jaw and pointed chin), microcephaly, limb and facial asymmetry, 5th finger clinodactyly.
  • A few cases are due to genomic imprinting disorder involving chromosome 11. 

Note: Triangular facies is also seen in Alagille syndrome.

The image given below shows a child with Russell–Silver syndrome.

questions.text: During an intersectoral collaborative event, an award-winning geneticist from the National Human Genome Research Institute is invited for an endowment oration. He presents his lecture on an experimental form of treatment that uses the transfer of genetic material to cure diseases known as 'Gene Therapy'. Which of the following techniques does he mention for this therapy?
questions.solution:
Electroporation is used in gene therapy.

Gene therapy is a technique that uses genes to treat or prevent disease through the delivery of DNA into a patient's cell by using recombinant viruses/naked DNA/DNA complexes. The methods used include intranuclear injection, electroporation, gene-gun, sonoporation, and magnetofection.

Gene therapy was first used for severe combined immunodeficiency disorder (SCID), which is due to adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency.

FDA-approved gene therapy is used for SCID, Leber's congenital amaurosis, multiple myeloma, and adrenoleukodystrophy.

questions.text: The following is the finding noted in a 12-month-old baby who is growing well and developing normally since birth. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this finding?

choices.text: Maternal history of phenytoin intake during pregnancy should be suspected
Chromosomal analysis should be done to rule out other chromosomal abnormalities

questions.solution:
The picture depicts a Simian crease – a single transverse palmar crease. It is a normal finding in about 3% of the population. In a child with simian crease and normal growth and development, reassurance should be provided. 

  • A simian crease is one of the findings of Down's syndrome however presence of only this finding should not lead to a diagnosis of Down's syndrome.
  • Maternal history of phenytoin intake during pregnancy does not lead to this finding. However, maternal alcohol intake can be associated with this condition.
  • Chromosomal analysis in an otherwise well child is not indicated.

questions.text: Non-invasive prenatal screening (NIPS) is particularly useful in the modern era of diagnosis in clinical genetics. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this test?

choices.text: Evaluates maternal blood for fetal abnormalities
Positive test need confirmation by invasive testing

questions.solution:
Non-invasive prenatal screening (NIPS) has a high negative predictive value. 

NIPS:

  • Useful in screening high-risk pregnancies for aneuploidies.
  • Done after 10 weeks of gestation.
  • Evaluates maternal blood for screening.
  • Positive tests need confirmation by invasive testing (like amniocentesis, chorionic villous sampling).
